div.head: f [1] (15 November) (Hampton Court)
div.ab: After our very hartie commendacions ffor so much as yt is found by experience that very great perill and incoueniences hath fallen vppon soundry of the Queenes Maiestes subiectes by the sufferance of great assemblies of people to come together at plaies and shewes neare London in this tyme of Contagion and infection of the plague: And for the restraint thereof straicte order hath ben taken in the Citie and the liberties of the same. Theis be to requier youe forthwith to giue commaundement, as so directed by vs that there be no playes shewes nor any such vnnecessarie assemblies vsed in that Countie within ten myles of the Citie vntill Easter next vppon payne of imprisonement to such as shall in any wies offend to the contrarie. And thervnto youe must take spciallspciall: for speciall regarde. ffarre youe hartely well ffrom Hampton Court the xvth of Nouember 1574

div.p: An oblong tear on the left side of the manuscript has obscured some letters before the legible signatures. The first damaged signature may have been by Ralph Sadler, identified in the Acts of the Privy Council for the meeting on 15 November as present (see Acts of the Privy Council, vol 8, pp 301–26, British History Online, accessed 23 July 2024). William Bray has identified, in the 19th-c. ink below, the signature of Nicholas Bacon, who appears to have signed with the initials 'C s' for 'Custos sigili' (keeper of the seal). There is also an oblong tear in the manuscript where the seal was ripped off, obliterating the word before 'ffrendes' and the 'Ar' of Arundell, but possibly more letters for Henry Fitzalan (1512–80), twenty-fourth earl of Arundel.

Besides the earl of Arundel, the privy councillors signing the letter are as follows: Sir Nicholas Bacon (1510–79), lord keeper of the Great Seal, 1558–79; Sir William Cecil (1520/21–98), first Baron Burghley, lord treasurer, 1572–98; Edward Clinton (1512–85), sixteenth earl of Lincoln, lord admiral, 1559–85; Ambrose Dudley (c 1530–90), twenty-first earl of Warwick; Sir Francis Knollys (1511/12–96), treasurer of the Household, 1570–96; Sir James Croft (c 1518–90), comptroller of the Household, 1570–90; Sir Thomas Smith (1513–77), secretary of State, 1572–7; Robert Dudley (1532/3–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester; and Sir Francis Walsingham (c 1532–90), principal secretary, 1573–90.

div.head: f 87v (13 July)
div.ab: Newinton

row.cell: ffirsteSavage & Hilles presente Ierome Savadge & Iohn Hilles to skowre & caste deeper x roddes of their common shewer leadinge from the grate at newington Buttes to the ende of Ierome Savages orchard corner beinge more or les to be done by the xth daye of October nexte comynge vppon paine of xx d. for euerye rod then vndone

Itemthenhabitantes of Newintonwe presente thenhabitance of ‸the parishe of Newington to clense & caste deeper one rodde before the grate of Ierome Savadges doore to be done by the xth of October next comynge vpon paine of vj s. viij d. yf it be then vndone

WeHilles & Cockowepresente Iohn hills & Thomas Cockowe to skowre & caste deeper xv pooles of the common shewer leadinge from Ierome Savages orchard corner to barloweses grounde be it more or les to be done by the xth daye of October next comynge vpon paine of xx d. euery rod then vndone

div.p: Jerome Savage (d. 1587) is known to have been an actor in the earl of Warwick's troupe between 1575–9. See further History of the Playhouse.

John Hilles' property apparently lay to the south of the 'common sewer,' which ran between them on the south edge of Savage's lot (Ingram Business of Playing, pp 160–2). For Thomas Cuckowe, named in the third entry, see the 1590 lease, CCA: Register W, CCA-DCc- Register/W, ff 36v–7.
On 21 July 1576 (f 90v), Jerome Savage's name appears listed with others 'which performed' tasks.

row.cell: Imprimis Newington St Georges & St Mary Magdalynswe present all thos persons whose names are herevnder named hauing grounde within the saied parishes to cutt & dragge all theire seuerall partes of the Comen shewer begyninge at the grate at Newington Buttes & so all alonge to the bridge at the Lasier house viz: IohnIohn: presumably an error for Ierome Savadge & Iohn Hilles x roddes

div.p: Savage's name continues to appear in combination with Hilles in the Sewer Commission records until November 1578.

div.head: f 105v (3 November)
div.ab:
The parishes of Newington St Georges
Reddereth & Mary Magdalyns

row.cell: Item we present all the landhoulders from Newington bridge vppon both sydes the Comen sewer & so alonge to Duffildes sluce to Cutt pare & dragge all & euery man his seuerall parte of the same sewer to be done by the laste daye of November next comyng vppon payne of xij d. for euery rodde then vndone viz.

div.head: f 27v (June)
div.ab: Item yt ys agreyd that peter honybourne shall haue a lease of the resydue of the garden adioyni and groundes adioynyng to the playe house in newyngton not comprised in his former lease for xxjti yeres to begynne at michaelmas next and he to pay therefore yerely two shillinges

div.p: The date of the chapter meeting on f 25 has been damaged by fire; the exact date in June is lost. The original foliation for the entry was 4v.

row.cell: WeHonningborne. present Peter Honningborne to open the sluce by the play house that the water may hav a fre passage by our Ladyday nextour Ladyday next: feast of the Annunciation, 25 March vpon payn of

WeCuckow
exstreted present Richard Cuckow to make asluce or thorough at his gate leading in to his feild next adioyning to the playhouse by our Lady day next. vppon paine of

div.p: For Richard Cuckow see the 1590 lease, CCA: Register W, CCA-DCc- Register/W, ff 36v–7.

div.head: p 440 (25 July) (Greenwich)
div.ab: AA: in display script Lettre to the Lord maior of the Cyttie of London, and the Iustices of midlesexmidlesex: 3 minims for mi and Surrey. Whereas heretofore there hathe ben order taken to restraine the playinge of Enterludes and playes on the Sabothe daie, Notwithstandinge the which (as wee are enformed), the same ys neglected to the prophanacion of this daie, and all other daies of the weeke in divers places the players doe vse to Recyte theire plaies to the great hurt and destruction of the game of Beare Baytinge and lyke pastymes which are maynteyned for her maiestes pleasure yf occacion require: These shalbe therefore to Requiere yow not onlie to take order hereafter that there maie no plaies Interludes or Commodyes be vsed or publicklie made and shewed either on the Sondaie or on the Thursdaies, because on the Thursdayes those other games vsuallie haue ben allwayes accustomed and practized. Whereof see yow faile not hereafter to see this our order dulie observed for the avoydinge of the Inconveniences aforesaid./

div.p: Although authorities in London and Middlesex were also addressed here, this letter provides evidence that the proximity – and competition – offered to the long-standing Bear Garden in Southwark by Henslowe's Rose and the Lord Strange's Men, likely resident there by this time, was of growing concern. Whether the playhouse at Newington Butts was used by players during this period is unknown.

The privy councillors listed as present at the meeting (p 436) were John Whitgift (c 1530–1604), archbishop of Canterbury, 1583–1604; Sir Christopher Hatton (c 1540–91), lord chancellor, 1587–91; Sir William Cecil (1520/21–98), lord treasurer, 1572–98; Thomas Sackville (c 1536–1608), first Baron Buckhurst, privy councillor, 1586–1608; Sir Francis Knollys (1511/12–96), treasurer of the Household, 1570–96; Sir Thomas Heneage (c 1532–95), vice-chamberlain of the Household, 1587–95; Sir John Wolley (d.1596), privy councillor, 1586–96; and Sir John Fortescue (1533–1607), privy councillor, 1588–1607.

div.head: single sheet
div.ab: ThatThat: T in display script8 for avoydinge of great concourse of people, Which causeth increase of thinfection, yt were convenient, that all Playes, Bearebaytinges, Cockpittes, common Bowlinge alleyes, and suche like vnnecessarie assemblies should be suppressed duringe the tyme of infection, for that infected people, after theire longe keepinge in, and before they be clered of theire disease and infection, beinge desirous of recreacion, vse to resort to suche assemblies, where throughe heate and thronge, they infecte manie sound personnes./

div.head: pp 211–12 (28 January) (Hampton Court)
div.ab:
AA: in display script lettre to the lord Maiour and Aldermen of the Cittie of london forasmuch as by the Certificate of the last weeke, yt appearethe the infection dothe increase, which by the favour of God, and with your dilligent obseruance of her Maiestes Comandementes and the meanes and orders prescribed to be put in execution within the Cittie of london maie speedelie cease yeat for the better furderance therof we think yt fitt that all manner of concourse and publique meetinges of the people at playes, beare baitinges, bowlinges, and other like assemblyes for sportes be forbidden, and therefore doe hereby requier you and in her Maiestes name straightlie charge and commande you forthwith to inhibite within your Iurisdiction all plaies baiting of beares, bulls, Bowling and any other like occasions to assemble any nombers of people together (preacheing and devyne seruice at Churches excepted) wherby no occasions be offred to increase the infection within the Cittie, which you shall doe bothe by
proclamacion to be published to that ende and by spetiall watche and obseruacion to be had at the places where the Plaies bearebaitinges bowlinges and like pastimes are vsually frequented and if you shall vpon this publicaonpublicaon: for publicacion; abbreviation mark missing finde any so vnduitifull and disobedient as they will, notwithstanding this prohibition offer to plaie, beate beares or bulles bowle &c. you shall presentelie cause them to be apprehended and comitted to prison there to remaine vntill by their order they shalbe dismissed And to the end the like assemblies within the out liberties adioyning to the Cittie we haue giuen direction to the Iustices of the peace, and other publique officers of the Counties of Middlesex and Surrey to hold the like course not onlie within the said liberties but also within the distance of seven myles about the Cittie which we doubte not they will carefullie see to be executed as you for your parte within the Cittie will doe the like, in regarde of her Maiestes comandement the benefitt of the Cittie; and for the respectes alreadie signified vnto you.

Two other lettres of the like tenour written to the Iustices of the peace within the Counties of Surrey and Middelsex for the prohibition of like assemblies in the out liberties and within seven miles of the Cittie of either Countie.

div.p: The privy councillors listed as present at the meeting (p 209) were John Whitgift (c 1530–1604), archbishop of Canterbury, 1583–1604; Sir John Puckering (1543/4–96), lord keeper of the Great Seal, 1592–6; Charles Howard (1536–1624), lord admiral, 1585–1619; Henry Carey (1526–96), lord chamberlain of the Household, 1585–96; Sir Thomas Sackville (c 1536–1608), first Baron Buckhurst, privy councillor, 1586–1608; Sir Thomas Heneage (c 1532–95), vice-chamberlain of the Household, 1587–95; Sir Robert Cecil (1536–1612), privy councillor, 1591–1612; Sir John Wolley (d.1596), privy councillor,1586–96; and Sir John Fortescue (1533–1607), privy councillor, 1588–1607.

div.head: f 184 (6 July)
div.ab: Yt is agreed that Mr Paule Bucke shall have the leases of t tenemente and plaiehouse thereto adioyninge in Newington renewed vp to xxj yeares with covenauntes as before and with a clause that he shall convert the playehouse to some other house vse vppon the saide grownde and not suffer anie plaies there after michelmas nexte

div.p: The date of this agreement for Buck's lease of the Lurklane property comes soon after Henslowe's use of the Newington Butts playhouse for the newly formed Lord Chamberlain's and Lord Admiral's Men in June 1594. Both Ingram, Business of Playing, p 176, n 48, and Wickham et al, English Professional Theatre, p 329, use the older ink folio number 153 for this entry.

div.head: f 9 (3–13 June)
div.ab:
In the name of god Amen begininge at newing
ton my Lord Admeralles men & my Lorde chamberlenes
men As ffolowethe 1594

row.cell: Receued at the Iewe of malta
¶ 8 of Iune 1594 nene: evidently written after first writing
Receued at bellendon XX: written over line filler, evidently after first writing
Receued at the tamynge of A shrowe

div.p: For further details on the plays listed, see Appendix 2. Henslowe drew a line following the entry on 13 June before continuing with his receipts from performances following, from 15 June onward. The Taming of a Shrew and Titus Andronicus do not appear again in the repertory recorded in the Diary and scholars have generally agreed that the Admiral's and Chamberlain's Men did not continue together at the Newington playhouse after their brief run there ending 13 June 1594.

div.head: f 294a v (5 October)
div.ab:
Item Cuckowe
fface
Salter
miller
Iefferson
Harvy we fynd that the sewar leadinge from the houses where the old playe house did stand att Newington all alongest vnto the Bridge goyng from Barmondsey cross the high waye vnto sainct Thomas Wateringes is needefull to be cast clensed and scowred, and we fynd that Richard Cuckow Robert fface, Richard Salter Iohn miller, Iohn Iefferson and Thomas Harvy oughte to cast clense and scower the same We present the same to be done before Candlemas next vpon payne of every pole then vndone
ij s. vj d.
done

div.p: This final notice of the 'old playe house' in the Sewer Commission records indicates that the building had been demolished before 1599 and possibly around the time that Buck assumed the lease. 'St. Thomas à Waterings was situated close to the second milestone on the Old Kent Road, and was so called from a brook or spring, dedicated to St. Thomas à Becket.' See Edward Walford, 'The Old Kent Road,' in Old and New London: Volume 6 (London, 1878), 248–255, British History Online http://www.british-history.ac.uk/old-new-london/vol6/pp248-255, [accessed 27 July 2024].

div.head: mb 3 (Bill of complaint)
div.ab:
ToTo: display initial T the Quenes most excellent
maiestie

InIn: display initial I most humble wise sheweth vnto your most excellent maiestie your maiesties humble and obedient Subiect Ierom Savage that where one RichardeRicharde: written over erasure Tomson had by good conveyance for terme of xixte yeres in and to one messuage with the appurtenanaunces in Newington in the countie of Surrey wherin your said Subiect now inhabiteth and he the said Thomas beinge therof soo possessed conveyed hys interest aforesaid therein to your said Subiect by force whereof your said Subiect entered and was possessed accordingly & your said Subiect havinge the premisses by such title was desirous to procure further yeres as also to have estaite in hys owne right from him that claymed the inheritance of the premisses That ys to say of one Richard Hickes and therevpon your said Subiect moved the said Richard Hickes who then affirmed to have the verie fee simple of the premisses & that he had full poer to graunte the same to your said Orator for such yeres as they concluded to have the same for terme of 30 yeres & therevpon for the some of x li.x li.: written over erasure paid by your said Orator the said Richard Hikes at or about thannunciacion of our Ladie in the xviijth yere xviijth yere: 1576 of your maiesties reigne dyd by hys sufficient deed lett the said messuage and one orchard and garden with thappurtenaunces for terme of 30 yeres then next followinge reseruinge yerely during the said terme ffoure markes of good and lawfull money of England payable quarterlie at ffoure termes in the yere yat ys to say at the feastes of the Natiuitie of St Iohn Baptist & St Mychell tharcaungell & the natiuitie of our Lord God and thannunciacion of our Lady by even porcions And in the said lease ther was one condicion or prouiso by yat which yt was provided that yf the said Rent or any part therof were behind in parte or in all at any feast or day aforesaid wherin the said Rent ought to be paid & by xiiijth daies after being lawfullie d‸emaunded yat then yt should be lawfull to & for the said Richard hys heires & assignes to enter and yt to have & repossedrepossed: for repossessed; abbreviation mark missing as in hys first & former estate And by force of such Lease your said subiect entred & was possessed of now so yt ys & yt may please your most excellent maiestie yat the said Richard Hikes sekinge to defeat your said Subiect of the premisses contrarie to hys owne graunte & to prefer one Peter Hunnyngborne hys sonne in law to the same first pretend that the said Peter had & hath of the said Richard a former graunte before the said seconde lease & publish the said lease wher ether ther ys no such lease or yf ther were any the same was antedated or made onely upon trust betwen the said parties & not to thuse of the said Peter but by fraude & coven to deceive such to whome the said Richard should lett the premisses and the said Richard & Peter fearinge & suspectinge that such former lease as they published yf any ther be will not be sufficient to defeat such the estate of your highnes subiect so made bona fide for good consideracions the said Richard by secret practise withe the said Peter as the said Peter firmethfirmeth: small hole in MS hath made secret estate to the said Peter of the reuercion of the premisses to thend yat he the said Peter by some arte & practice might the sooner cume to hys determined purposse to procure the possession of the premisses to him self & to defeat by craft your said Subiectes lease by reason that your said subiect knew not of any such assurance as the said Peter now pretendeth And so yt ys & yt may please your highnes yat after the feast of thannunciacion of our Lady last past & before the xiiij day after your said subiect left ye said Rent due at the said feast which one Thomas whasewhase: h corrected over another letter whom your maiestie havinge occasion to go about hys affaires left in the said house commaundinge him to pay ye said Rent to ye said Richard Hikes before or at the said xiiijth day which the said Richard & Peter vnderstandinge cam not to demaund the same Rent so that xiijth daies passinge & the said Thomas whasewhase: corrected over erasure suspecting no fraude vpon the xiiijth day went to london aboute hys affaires as also hopinge to mett ther with the said Richard Hikes to pay the said some not knowinge that the some was to be renderet on the lande nor suspectinge such the practice of the said Richard and Peter & your said Subiect hopeth to prove that by secret meanes vsed by the said Peter yat the said Thomas was procured to go to the said cytty yat day he the said Thomas nothinge suspectinge such practice And true yt ys & yt may please your highnes yat after yat the said Thomas was departed to london the aforesaid honyngborne havinge knowledg therof came to the aforesaid messuage & ther demaunded the said Rent sumtymes as yt ys said in hys owne & sumtymes in the name of ye said Richard & for default of payment as he the said Peter reporteth made hys entrie into the said messuage and after ye said Thomas cumminge to the said messuage within half an houre after & hearinge of the same demaunde retorned to the house of the said Peter in London imed‸iate the same day & ther offered to pay the same Rent & declared yat he had ye same longe before redy to haue paid yt by the deliuerye & commaundement of your maiesties said Subiect but at the first the ‸said Peter refused to receive the same & after ye same day your highnes said Subiect likewise after came to the house of the said Peter & made tender of the saide Rent which the said Peter awhyle refused Neuerthelesse the same Peter afterwardes the same day ‸by his wif receyved the same Rent & she deliuered ‸it to the said Peter who yet hath the same & held the premisses notwithstandinge the said Peter & Richard by such contynuall practice seeke still to frustrate and make void the interest of your said Subiect by such ther indirect & extreame dealinge Notwithstandinge the receipte of the said rente and for that in extremitie of law some perillperill: corrected over erasure in fresh ink in the premisses may insue to your said Subiect onelesse the truthe in the premisses may appere by the corporall othe of the said saidsaid said: dittography Richard & Peter May yt ‸therefore pleasse your most excellent maiestie to graunt your maiesties wryt of Prevy seale to be directed to the said Pete Richard and Peter commaundinge them & either of them therby at a certaine day and vnder a certaine paine ther in to be limytted personally to appere before your maiesties honorable court of Requestes then & ther to aunswere the premisses And your maiesties said Subiect shall dayly pray to god for the longe & prosperus contynuance of your maiesties reigne etc

div.head: mb 2 (10 May) (Answer of Peter Hunningborne)
div.ab:
TheThe: in display scriptxo Die Maij Anno Regine answere of Peter Honingborne Defendant to
the Elizabeth xixo Bill of Complaint of Ierom Savage Complainant

TheThe: display initial T saide Defendant saithe That the saide Bill against him exhibited for the most parte of the matters therein conteyned is vncerteine vntrewe and insufficient in the lawe As he thinketh to be answered vnto not concerninge anie matter of Substaunce or effecte Worthie to trouble this Honourable Court withall and is sett fourthe and devised as he beleaveth by the Complainant rather of malice and envey to greave Charge and vexe this Defendant then for anie good grounde or Cause of svte Nevertheles if this Defendant by order of this Courte shalbe compelled to make anie further answere vnto the ‸said vncerteine and insufficient Bill of Complaint Then the advantage and exception to the incertentie and insvfficiencye of the saide Bill vnto this Defendant at all tymes hereafter saved for answere and declaracion of the treuth of suche thinges Conteyned in the saide Bill as Concerneth this defendant Materiall to be answered vnto he saieth that as towchinge the messwage with the appurtenaunces in the Countie of SussexSussex: likely for Surrey wherein the saide Complainant saieth that he nowe dwelleth which as he saieth he had of one Thomas Thomson in whome he supposethe a former possession of the said premisses, this Defendant knowethe noe suche thinge, But in trewthe this Defendant saiethe That one Richarde Thomson as this Defendant thinketh had and held one messwage or Tenement nere Newington Buttes in the Countie of Surrey as Tenaunte to Richarde Hickes in the saide Bill of Complaynt named but how or by what title this defendant knoweth not And this Defendant further saiethe that after the Departure of the saide Richarde Thomson beinge a silkewever as this Defendant thinkethe The saied Complainant occupied the same messwage or tenemente and he so havinge the occupacion of the saide house sought by all meanes that he coulde to obteyne of the saide Richarde Hickes to whome the premisses was by the Cheif Landlorde of the premisses graunted for manie yeres yet to come a lease for Thirtie yeares of the saide Messwage or tenemente And the same Complainant thinckinge and entendinge as it semeth and as the said Complainant hym seulf saide to entrapp the saide Richarde Hickes being a symple and plaine dealinge man whom the saide complainant aswell therein as otherwaies hathe abused, did Cause to be inserted in the Indenture ‸of lease a Covenaunt Whereby the saide Richarde did stand bounde that he had full power right and Aucthoritie to Demise and graunt the saide Messwage or tenemente and other the premisses in the saide lease graunted, in suche sorte as in the same deed is expressed. And the saide Complainant givinge but Tenne Poundes for suche his lease procured the saide Richard Hickes to seale a bond of a Hundered Poundes to performe covenauntes meaninge thereby to make him forfeit his bond ymediatlie after the sealing thereof. Whiche saide Indenture of Lease graunted by the said Richard Hickes to the saide Complainant was vppon Divers Condicions. That is to saie That if the yerelie rent of ffiftie Three shillinges and ffower Pence therefore reserved should be behind vnpaid in parte or in all, by the space of xiiijtene Daies over or after anie feast or terme of paymente in the said Indenture of lease lymited and beinge lawfullie asked. Or if the saide Complainant his executors administrators or assignes should breake or make defaulte in performance of anie Covenaunte graunt Article or agrement in the saide Indenture mencioned Which on his and their partes or of on the behalf of anie of them were or oughte to be performed by the trew intentes and meanigesmeaniges: for meaninges abbreviation mark missing of the saide Indenture That then and from thensfourth the saide demise and lease should cease be fullie determined and of none effecte and that then and at all tymes after it should be lawfull to and for the saide Richarde Hickes his executors and assignes into the saide tenement and other the premisses with Thappurtenaunces wholie to reenter and the same as ‸in his or there former estate to have againe retaine and repossede, And the said Complainant his executors and assignes and all others occupiynge the same premisses from thense vtterlie to expell amove and put oute forever, anie thinge in the saide Indenture of lease conteyned to the Contrarie notwithstandinge as by the saide Indenture of Demise more at large maie appeare after whiche saide Lease ‸to the said Complainant mad the saide Richarde Hickes beinge by obligacion vnder his hande and Seall Lawfullie and iustlie indebted to this Defendant in the some of fiftie Poundes for the payment whereof he stoode bound to the said Defendant in one obligacion of one hundredth markes and for non payment thereof beinge sved at the Comon lawe by this defendant and the matter reddie to come to triall by Nysi prius fell to Composicion with this defendant and for satisfacion thereof amongest other thinges the saide Richard Hickes did graunt the revercion of the said premisses to the saide defendant for Divers yeres yet to come Wherevnto the saide Complainant consented and did acknowledge the saide Defendant as his Landlord by vertue whereof the said Defendant was possessed thereof accordinglie and afterwardes this Defendant cominge to the foresaid Messwage or Tenement as is aforesaide demised, gentlie demanded his rent on the ffowertenth daie after the ffeast daie of Thanunciacion of oure Ladie Saint Marie the virgen in the Nynetenth yere of the Reigne of oure Soveraigne Ladie Elizabeth the Queenes MaiestieNynetenth…Maiestie: ie, 1577 that nowe is Dewe at the saide ffeast of Thanunciacion of oure Ladie and there taried for the same one hole hower in the latter parte of the daie even vntell the sonne was sett and the daie finished and yet Could gett noe rent or other money dewe Wherevppon this defendant Imediatlie reentred which he neded not to have done for that the lease and interest of the saide Complainant by the said demaunde was mad void ipso facto)facto): opening parens omitted likely before which without anie reentrey and further this defendant saieth that he with workmen accordinge to a couenant and Condicion conteyned in the saide lease came to viewe the reperacions, and Could not be suffered to enter and veiw accordinge to the saide Covenaunt and Condicion but those that kepte the house vtterlie denies him so to doe and shutt the dore against him By reason whereof also the Lease was voide and Determined. And when this defendant Cometh thether meaninge to talke friendlie and deale Curtiouslie with the saide Complainant, althoughe his sertes be otherwise. The same Complanant giveth vnto the Defendant Threteninge wordes and fecheth his sword to thende as this defendant is induced to beleave, to stricke this defendant. And the saide Complainant braggeth and bosteth that he hathe suche freindes as shall Compell this Defendant to deale in suche sort as pleasethe him And in trewthe the complainant himsealf is a verrie lewed feallowe and liveth by noe other trade then playinge of staige plaies and Interlevdes to the knoledge of this defendant and for his lewde and lose lief hath Comaundement from the ordenarye as is Crediblie reported to avoide out of that parishe which his lewed behavior would sone make an honest man werie of so weked : 38mm of text faded tenant And so muche the more because the mor because the honest neighboures in that place doe so mislike his behavior as they will not suffer hime to Dwell there anie longer althoughe as it is void And althoughe the defendant for his parte would be contented to allowe the same. Which he cannot Convenientlie doe because in trewthe this defendant is in greate need of a house and therefore meanethe to dwell there him sealf whereof by the : 50mm of faded text followed by 75mm of line filler And bycause he cold not hold the same by him sealf he did sett a Bill on the dore to sell or doe awaie the same And this defendant further saiethe that he did not practise anie measur to defeat the Complainant of his Interest otherwise then by the demand of his saide Rent as Lawfullie it was for him to doe without that. that by anie secreat meanes vsed by the saide defendant that the said Thomas whast in the said Bill of Complaint named was procured to goe to the Cittie of London that daie Whereon the saide demaund was made as in the said Bill is most falselie and vntrulie surmised. ffor in verry trewth this defendant tarried a great while for his rent Could get none or hard of anie suche fellowe. And without that that the saide rent was that daie paied to this defendant as in the said Bill is also vntrulie aledged. And without that that anie other matter or thinge Comprehended in the said Bill Materiall to be answered vnto And in this answere not sufficientlie answered or confessed and avoided Denied or traversed as this defendant belaeaveth is trew in manner and forme as in the said Bill is Contteyned All which matters this defendant is reddie to Averr and prove as this honorable Court shall awarde And praieth to be dismissed with his resonable costes in this behalf wrongfullie sussteyned

div.head: mb 1 (17 May) (Answer of Richard Hickes)
div.ab:
Thexvijo die maij Anno Regine
Elizabeth xixo answere of Richard Hickes defendant to the Bill of Complaint
of Ierome Savage Complanante

The saide Defendant saiethe that the said Bill of Complainte against him exhibited for the moste parte of the matters therein Conteyned as concerne this defendant is vncerteyne vntrewe and insufficiente in the Lawe as he thincketh to be answered vnto not ConteyningeConteyninge: 4 minims for nin any matter of substaunce or effecte Worthie to troble this honnorable Courte with all and is set fourth and devised by the complanant as he beleaveth rather of Crafte envye and mallice to entrape thargetharge: for the charge (?) and vexe this Defendant then for anie good ground or Cause of sute Neverthelesse if this defendant by the order of this Honnorable Courte shalbe Compelled to make anie further answere vnto the said vncerteine and insufficient Bill of Complainte Then the Advantage and excepcion to the incertenty and insufficyencye of the saide Bill vnto this Defendant at all tymes hereafter saved for answere and declaracion of the truthe of suche thinges Conteyned in the said Bill as concerneth this Defendant materiall to be answered vnto he saiethe That as towchinge the messwage with Thappurtenaunces in Newington in the Countie of SussexSussex: for Surrey wherein the saied Complainant saieth that he nowe dwelleth which as he saieth he had of one Thomas Thomson whome he supposeth a farmer in the possession of the saide premisses This Defendant knoweth noe suche thinge But in truthe this defendant saiethe That one Richard Thomson as this Defendaunt remembreth had and held one messwage or Tenement nere Newington Buttes in the Countie of Surrey as tenaunt to this defendant And this defendant further saiethe that after the departure of the saied Richard Thomson beinge a silkewever as this defendante remembreth The said Complanant occupied the saide messwage or Tenemente and he so havinge the occupacion of the saide house sought by all meanes that he could to obteyne of him this defendant to whom the premisses was by the Cheif Landlord of the premisses graunted for manie yeares yet to come a lease for Thirtie yeres of the saide messwage or Tenemente And the same Complainant thinkinge and entendinge as it seameth as he hym sealf hath saied to entrape the said Defendant beinge a simple and plaine delinge man whom the Complainant as well therein as in other thinges hathe greatlie abused did cause to be inse‸rted in the said Indenture of Lease a Covenaunte whereby this defendant did stand bounde that he had full power right and aucthoritie to Demise and graunt the said messwage, or tenement and other the premisses in the saide Indenture of Lease graunted in suche sort as in the saide Deed is expressed. And the same Complaynaunt givinge but Tenn Poundes for such his lease procured the saide Defendaunt beinge simple and givinge over muche Credite to the feyer wordes of the saide Complanant to seall a Bonde of a Hundered Poundes to performe the covenauntes And in trewth as it semeth the same Complanant ment to make this Defendant forfecte his bond ymedyatlie after the sealinge thereof Which saide Indenture of lease graunted by this defendante to the saide Complainant was vppon divers Condicions that is to saie That if the yerelie rente of ffiftie Three shillinges and ffower Pence thereby for the premises reserved should be behinde vnpaied in part or in all by the space of ffourteane Daies over or after anie feast or terme of paymente in the saide Indenture of lease lymited and beinge Lawfullie asked. Or if the saide Complainant his executours administratours or assignes should breake or make defaulte in performaunce of anie Covenaunte article or Agremente in the saide Indenture mencioned which on his and their partes or on the behouf of anie of them were or ought to be performed by the trewe entent and meaninge of the saide Indenture. That then and from thensfourth the saide demise and lease should cease be fullie determined and of none effecte And that then and at all tymes after it should be lawfull to and for this defendant his executours and assignes into the saide tenement and other the premisses with Thappurtenaunces wholie to reenter And the same as in his or there former estate to have againe retaine and reposses. And the saide Complanant his executours and assignes and all others occupiinge the same premisses from theise vtterlie to expell amove and put out forever Anie thinge in the saide Indenture of Lease conteyned to the Contrary notwithstandinge As by the said Indenture of Demise more at large maie appeare, After whiche saide lease to the saide Complanant made this defendant beinge before that by obligacion vnder his hande and Seale lawfullie lawfullielawfullie lawfullie: dittography at the beginning of the line and Iustlie indebted to Peter Honningborne one of the defendantes in the saide Bill of Complainte named in the some of ffiftie Poundes for the payment whereof he this defendaunt stoode bound to the saide Peter Honingborne by the saide obligacion in one Hundereth markes And for none payment thereof beinge sved at the common Lawe by the saide Peter Honingborne and the matter redye to come to tryall by Nisi prius this Defendant fell to Composicion with the saide Peter Honingborne And for satisfacion thereof amongest other thinges this defendant did graunt aswell the revercion of the premisses as the revercion of Two other tenementes in the parrishe of Saint Olaves in Southworke in the Countie of Surrey by this defendant before that demised to one Thomas Cranage Ioynte to the saide Peter Honingborne for Divers yeres yet to come wherevnto the saide Complanant Consented and did acknowledge the saide Peter Honingborne as his Landlord as this defendant hathe bene Credeblie enformed And as this defendant hath gathered by the Complanantes owne wordes By vertue whereof the said Peter Honingborne was possessed thereof accordingly And afterwardes as this defendant hath herd the saide Peter Honingborne the ffowertenth Daie after the ffeast of Thanuncyacion of our Ladie Saint Marie the Virgin in the xixth yere xixth yere: 1577 of the raigne of our Sovereigne Ladie the Queenes Maiestie that nowe is made his demaunde for the rent dewe at the feast aforesaide and for none payment thereof reentered And by reason of suche demaunde made the Complanantes lease voide as this defendant thinckethe And also this defendant hath herd it Credably reported that the said Peter Honingborne with workmen accordinge to a Convenaunte and proviso conteyned in the saide Lease Came to the premises to viewe the reparacions thereof which was to him denied and the Dore shutt against him ‸which was another Cause whereby the lease should be voide And the saide Peter Honingborne hath tolde this defendant that he hath ben evill vsed and threatened by this said Complanant who make the great Bragges and saiethe he cane procure greate freindes to Countenaunce his matter And to force the saide Peter Honingborne to yeald to him as is said And yet in trewthe the saide Complainant is a Verrie lewde fellowe and his Cheifeste Manner of lyvinge is by playinge of interludes and for his lewde and loase life hath ben presented to the ordenarieOrdenarye: the archbishop's representative in the deanery of Croydon and is Comaunded by the Ordenarye as is saide to avoide the parishe which his lewde behavor wolde sone make an honeste man wearye of so Wicked an Idell a Lyvinge tennaunte And so much the more bennefite the honest neighboures in that place doe so mislike his behavioure as they will not suffer him to Dwell there which he Cannot Convenyentlie doe bycause in truth the saide Peter Honingborne is in great need of a house And there fore meanethe to Dwell there him sealf And also the Complanant freth not greatlie thereof as it seamethe for he hathe sett a Bill on the Dore to sell his interest And this defendant also saiethe : 20mm of text faded; approximately 9 characters he did not Practise anie meanes to defeat the Complanant of his Interest in the premisses but did graunt the revercion of the premisses Bona fide to the saide Peter Honingborne as is aforesaide And if the saide Complanant hathe given Cause of forfeiture of his Interest in the premisses this defendant cannot doe withall. Without that. that anie other matter or thinge Comprehended in the saide Bill of Complainte apperteyninge to this defendant Materiall to be answered vnto and in this answere not sufficiently answered or confessed and avoided denied or traversed as this defendant beleaveth is trewe in manner and forme as in the saide Bill of Complainte is conteyned All which matters this Defendant is redie to averr and prove as this honnorable Courte shall awarde And soe asmuche as it evidentlie appearethe that there was or is noe iust Cause whie this Defendant showld be molested or trobled he praieth therefore to be dismissed. this Honnorable Courte with his resonable Cost and Charges by him wrongfullie susteyned

div.p: Although the bill of complaint (mb 3) is not dated specifically, Savage's reference to the rent due by the feast of the Annunciation, 25 March, narrows the period to sometime in April or early May, before the answers of Hickes and Hunningborne were recorded.

div.head: p 300 (10 November) (Richmond)
div.ab: A lettre to Mr doctor Fourthe Robert Lewseye, Edward Bellingham & Barnard Randolphe Esquiers, to restraine certen players within the Bouroghe of Southewarke and other places nere adioyning within the Bouroghe of Southewarke and other places nere adioyning within that parte of Surreye, who by meanes of the alluring of the people ‸to their plaies doe augement the infection of ‸the plague in London; and if they shall not obeye their order to see them seuerely punished./

div.head: p 348 (23 December) (Richmond)
div.ab: A letter to the Lord Maior and the Iustices of Middlesex and Surrey, RequiringRequiring: 2 minims for in them to suffer the exercise of playes within the Cittie of London and ‸within the liberties, and to have regarde that suche orders as are prescribed for the stayingstaying: 2 minims for in of thinfection maie be duelie observed, so as ther growe no hurtehurte: u written over a vnto the soundre in their publicque assemblies./

div.p: Those named in the 10 November privy council letter were the JPs for Surrey. Edward Bellingham (c 1545-1605), was appointed JP in c 1573, according to HPO , accessed 23 July 2024. Bernard Randolph, JP of Middlesex, was also appointed JP for Surrey in 1567 (See Appendix One of William Baxter Robison III, 'The Justices of the Peace of Surrey in National and County Politics, 14831570,' 2 vols, PhD thesis (Louisiana State University, 1983), 403). No further information has been found for 'Mr doctor Fourthe' and 'Robert Lewseye.'

Privy councillors listed as present at the 10 November meeting (p 381) were Sir Nicholas Bacon (1510-79), keeper of the Great Seal, 1558-79; Sir William Cecil (1520/21-98), first Baron Burghley, lord treasurer, 1572–98; Thomas Radcliffe (1526/7-83), tenth earl of Sussex, lord chamberlain of the Household, 1572-83; Henry Fitzalan (1512-80), twenty-fourth earl of Arundel; Sir James Croft (c 1518-90), comptroller of the Household, 1570-90; Sir Christopher Hatton (c 1540–91), vice- chamberlain of the Household, 1577–87; and Sir Francis Walsingham (c 1532-90), principal secretary, 1573–90.

Privy councillors listed as present at the 23 December meeting (p 433) were Edward Clinton (1512-85), sixteenth earl of Lincoln, lord admiral, 1559-85; Ambrose Dudley (c 1530-90), twenty-first earl of Warwick; Robert Dudley (1532/3-88), fourteenth earl of Leicester; Sir Francis Knollys (1511/12-96), treasurer of the Household, 1570–96; Sir James Croft (c 1518-90), comptroller of the Household, 1570-90; and Sir Francis Walsingham (c 1532-90), principal secretary, 1573-90.

div.head: p 10 (13 May) (Westminster)
div.ab: A lettre to the Iustices of peace of the Countie of Surrie that whereas therr lordships do vnderstand that notwithstandinge therr late order geuen to the lord maior to for bidd all playes within and about the Cittie vntill Michalmas next for avoydinge of infection neuertheles certen players do playe sunderie daies euery weeke at newington buttes on that parte of Surrie without the Iurisdiccion of the said Lord Maior contrary to therr lordships order. therr lordships requier the Iustices not only to enquier who they be that disobey therr ComaundementComaundement: blot over t in that behalf and not only to forbidd them expresly for plyingplying: likely for playing in any of theis remote places nere vnto the Cittie vntill Michaelmas. but to haue regard that within the precincte of Surrie none be permitted to play if any do to comitt them and to aduertise/ &c

div.p: The last recorded performance at court by the earl of Warwick's players was 1 January 1579/80 (for lxvj s. viij d., TNA: E351/542, f 8), but it is possible that the company was still in residence at Newington Butts in May of the same year. Ingram, Business of Playing, pp 174–5, and Johnson, Shakespeare's Lost Playhouse, pp 89, 99, have speculated that the newly formed earl of Oxford's players, led by the Dutton brothers, may have used the playhouse next. How long Jerome Savage continued his tenancy is unclear, but by June 1582 Peter Hunningborne is on record in the Cathedral Chapter Act Book with a lease for the 'resydue of the gardenand groundes adioyning to the play house' , indicating the existence of an even earlier lease.

Savage had moved by 1582 to the parish of St Peter Westcheap, London, where he was assessed on £3 3s of goods in a lay subsidy roll for that year (TNA: E179/251/16, f 79). The baptism of Anne, one of his four daughters, was recorded on 19 March 1581/2 in the St Peter Westcheap parish register (LMA: P69/PET4/A/001/MS06502). Suzan, another daughter, was baptized 28 November 1585, but no baptismal dates have been found for Elizabeth, Faith, or Daniel, all named in their father's will. Although the surname Savage does not appear in St Peter Westcheap Churchwardens' Accounts between 1577-83, there is mention of a 'Mr Savage' under the Wood Street subheading in the receipts for 1583–4 (LMA: P69/PET4/B/006/MS00645/001, f 112). By November 1586 he was still resident there (TNA: E115/343/52, single sheet). He died soon after: his will is dated 31 January 1586/7, with a probate date of 18 February (see TNA: PROB 11/70/119).
The 'late order' refers to a plague order issued by the privy council to the JPs of Middlesex on 17 April 1580, to restrain plays on the outskirts of London until Michaelmas (TNA: PC2/12, p 812).

Privy councillors listed as present at this meeting (p 10) were Sir Thomas Bromley (c 1530–87), lord chancellor, 1579-87; Sir William Cecil (1520/21-98), first Baron Burghley, lord treasurer, 1572-98; Sir Christopher Hatton (c 1540–91), vice-chamberlain of the Household, 1577–87; Sir Francis Walsingham (c 1532-90), principal secretary, 1573-90; and Thomas Wilson (c 1523/4-81).

div.head: p 84 (11 May) (Greenwich)
div.ab: A lettre to the Iustices of Surrey: that according to suche direction as hathe ben geuen by their Lordships to the Lord Maior to restraine and inhibite the vse of plaies and interludes in publique places in and about the Cittie of London., in respect of the heat of the yeere now drawing on for thauoyding of the infection like to grow and increase by thordinarie assemblies of the people to those places they ar is‸ also required in like sorte to take order yat the playes & assemblies of the people at the Theater or anie other places about Newington bee forthwith restrained and forborne as aforesaid &c.

div.head: p 86
div.ab: A lettre to the Lord Maior: his lordship is desired according to his request made to their lordships by his lettres of the vijth of this present to geue order for the restrayning of playes and interludes within and about the Cittie of London for thauoyding of infection feared to grow and increase this tyme of Sommer by the Comon assemblies of people at those places, and that their lordships haue taken the like order for the prohibiting of the vse of playes at the Theater & thother places about newington out of his charge: and that according to his request their lordships haue geuen order for the reformeing of the disorder noted among the millners. &c.

div.p: The mayor's letter of 7 May has not yet been found.

Privy councillors listed as present at the 11 May meeting (p 89) were John Whitgift (c 1530–1604), archbishop of Canterbury, 1583–1604; Sir William Cecil (1520/21–98), first Baron Burghley, lord treasurer, 1572–98; , 1585–96; William Brooke (1527–97), tenth Lord Cobham, privy councillor, 1585–97; Sir Thomas Sackville (c 1536–1608), first Baron Buckhurst, privy councillor, 1586–1608; Sir Christopher Hatton (c 1540–91), lord chancellor, 1587–91; Sir Francis Knollys (1511/12–96), treasurer of the Household, 1570–96; and Sir Francis Walsingham (c 1532–90), principal secretary, 1573–90.

of the sayd landes now called

from thence next ensuinge and fullye to be compleate and ended Yealding payingepayinge: in display script therfore yearlye to the sayd Deane and Chapiter and to theire Suc the gate entringe to the foresayd tenn acres one Rodd fower dayeworkes and one pe land called Lurklane five poundes fowertene shillinges and fower pence of law money of England at fower vsuall termes in the yeare that is to Rychard for him his executors administrators and assignes Covenauntes and graunteth to and the sayd Deane and Chapiter and theire Successors by theise presentes that he the sa Rychard Cukcuk his conteininge in it the like wordes of demise Covenauntes and condicions reservacions and all other articles as is aforesayd for the which lease so to be graunted nofyne nor other payment shalbe of his and there possession and interest of and in this present demyse and terme of yeares and thervppon by payment of the rent or otherwyse become tennaunt to the sayd Deane and Chapiter and theire Successors And doe then also make payment to theire officers of such ordinary fees and dutyes as are accustomed to be payd for the sealinge and writinge of a lease which doth passe vnder theire common seale, That then and from thence forth this present Indenture lease and terme of yeares and every clause and article therin above one the behalf of the sayd Deane and Chapiter and theire Successors Chapiter the sayd Rychard Cukcuk hath sett his seale./ Dated in the Chapiter howse of the sayd Deane and Chapiter the day and yeare first above written./

div.p: The edge of folio 37 has been badly damaged by fire, with consequent loss of letters indicated by '.'

div.head: ff 265v–6 (5 April)
div.ab:
Thisenementum vocatum kelane prope outhwarke Paulo Buck dimissumenementum…dimissum: 'The tenement called Lurklane near Southwark demised to Paul Buck'; letters lost to fire damage along the left margin IndentureThis Indenture: in display script made the fifte daie of Aprill in the seauen and thirtith yeare of the raigne of our Soveraigne Ladye Elizabethseauen and thirtith yeare … Ladye Elizabeth: ie, 1595 by the grace of God Queen of Englande ffraunce and Irelande defendor of the faithe &c BetweneBetwene: in display script the Deane and chapiter of the Cathedrall and Metropoliticall Church of Christ of Canterburye of the one parte and Paule Bucke of the Cittie of London gent of the other parte wytnessethwytnesseth: in display script that whereas the said Deane and Chapiter by theire Indenture of Demise bearinge date the six and twentith daie of November in the Nynth yeare of the raigne of our said Soveraigne Ladye Queene ElizabethNynth yeare … Elizabeth: ie, 1566 did demise to Richard Hickes one of the yeomen of her Maiesties garde. All the thinges by theis presentes hereafter demised ToTo: display initial T haue and to hould to the said Richarde Hickes his executors and assignes from the feast of St Mychaell tharchangell then last past before the date of the saide Indenture vnto thend and terme of three scoare yeares. which said terme and the interest therein by good conveyaunce in lawe is sithence come to the handes and possession of the said Paule Buck. All which he the said Paule Buck hath surrendered to the said Deane and ChapChap: characters lost in binding
NoweNowe: in display script therefore the said Deane and Chapiter for and in Consideracion of said Surrender and for other good causes and Consideracions haue demised graunted and to ferme letten. And by theis presentes for them and theire suc doe demise graunte and to ferme let vnto the saide Paule Bucke All that theire M howse and tenement latelie builded by the foresaide Richarde Hickes vpon a parcell scituat and ‸beinge in newington neere Southwarke in the countee of Surrey called Lurklane letten as aforesaide to the saide Richarde Hickes amonge other landes togeither or garden plott as it is nowe inclosed out of the saide lande called Lurklane All howse and garden conteyneth in length alonge by the landes of the saide Deane and cha the tenure of the saide Richarde Hickes or his assignes towardes the northe fortye and six like length alonge by the Common Sewer there towardes the south ffortie fower yard bradth alonge by the Queens high waie there towardes the west thirtie six yardes And breadhbreadh: for breadth alonge by the landes of the saide Deane and Chapiter towardes the East twentie To haue andTo haue and: display script to houlde all the saide Messuage and tennement with thappurtenanc the saide Paule Buck his executors and assignes from the feaste of Ste Michaell th last past before the date of theis presentes vnto the full end of the ‸terme of twoe and thirtie yeares thence next ensuinge and fullie to bee compleate and ended yeldinge andyeldinge and: in display script paying th yearlie to the saide Deane and chapiter and there successors or to theire lawfull assign assignes the some of twelue shillinges of good and laufull monney of englande at the feastes thanuntiacion of the blessed Wirgin ‸virgin marye and St Michaell tharckaungell by even portions bee paide duringe the saide terme/ And the saydeAnd the sayde: in display script Paule Buck for him his executors admistrators and assignes Couenaunteth and graunteth to and with the saide Deane and Chapiter and there Successors by theis presentes. That he the saide Paule Bucke his executors administors and assignes at his and theire owne proper Costes Charges and expences shall in all thing duringe all the saide terme repaire vphoulde maintaine and sustaine the saide messuage and tennment and other the premisses and the same well and sufficientlie repaired into the handes of the saide Deane and Chapiter and theire successors, in thende of the saide terme to leave and yelde vp And yf it shall happenAnd yf … happen: in display script the saide yearelye rent or ferme of twelue shillinges or anie parte thereof to bee behinde and vnpaide by the space of one monneth next after anie of the daye of paymente abouesaide, in which it ought to to: followed by ink blot be paide/ Or yf the Reparacion of the saide messu or tennement and other the premisses (blank) by theis presentes demised be not within the space of one whole yeare next after monicion and warninge given by the Deane Receyvor general and or Surveyor of the landes and possessions of the saide Deane and Chapiter and theire successors for the tyme beinge to the saide Paule Buck his executors or assignes or to the occupiers occupiersoccupiers occupiers: dittography at beginning of line of the premisses for the due and needefull kepinge and repairinge thereof well and sufficientlye donne made mayntayned and repaired That then and from thence foorth this present Indenture amd every Clause and article therein vpon the behalfe of the saide deane and Chap above graunted to be vtterlye frustrate and of no force or effect anie thinge before mencio to the contrarye notwithstandinge/ In wytnes whereofIn wytnes whereof: in display script to one parte of this Indenture remayninge with the saide Paule Bucke the saide Deane and Chapiter haue set there common seale and to the other parte remayninge with the sayd Deane and ‸chapiter chapiter the saide Paule Bucke hath set his seale. Dated in the Chapiter howse of the saide Deane and Chapiter the daie and yeare first aboue written/

div.head: ff 266–6v (6 April)
div.ab:
Thisresiduum parcelle terre ibidem Paulo Buck dimissumresiduum … dimissum: 'The remainder of a parcel of land demised to Paul Buck' IndentureThis Indenture: in display script Made the Sixt daie of Aprill in the seauen and thirtith yeare the raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie Elizabeth by the grace of God Queene of Englande ffran and Irelande defendor of the faith &tc. BetweneBetwene: in display script the deane and Chapiter of the Cath and Metropoliticall Church of Christe of Canterburye of the one parte And Paule Bucke of ofof of: dittography at beginning of line London gent of the other parte/ Wytnesseth Wytnesseth: in display script that whereas the saide Deane and Ch by there Indenture of demise vnder theire common seale bearinge date the fifte daie of Ap in the seauen and thirtith yeare of the raigne of our saide Soueraigne Ladye Queene Eliza haue letten vnto the saide Paule Bucke. One Messuage or tennement scituat and beinge in Newington neere Southwarke in the Countie of Surrey latelie builded vpon a parcell of land there called Lurklane by one Richarde Hickes deceased togeither with a garden or garden as it was then enclosed in wchwch: for which; abbreviation mark missing lease certaine contentes of the lande therein enclosed are set downe which doe not conteyne the whole lande as it was inclosed by the saide Richarde Hic and as it nowe remayneth by fortye and eyght yardes in length and thirtie seaven yar and an half in breadth or abor there aboutes That wee the saide Deane and chapiter h demised graunted and to ferme letten, And by theis presentes doe demise graunte and to let to the saide Paule Bucke the residue of the full content of the landes inclosed
saide garden and garden plott not fullie sett downe in the saide former lease as it was inclosed and taken in by the saide Richarde Hickes in his lyfe time bearinge the content of ffourtie and eight yardes towardes the north and south and in breadth towardes the East ffortie and twoe yardes and in like breadth to the west thirtie and three yardes be it more or less To haue and to houldeTo haue … houlde: in display text the saide residue of the garden or garden plotte aforesaide to the saide Paule Buck his executors and assignes from the feaste of Thanuntiacion of the blessed Virgin Marye last past before the date of theis presentes vnto the full ende of the terme of twentie and one yeares from thence next ensuinge and fullie to bee compleate and ended yeldinge and Payingeyeldinge and Payinge: in display text therefore yearelye duringe the saide terme to the saide Deane and chapiter and theire successors the some of twoe shillinges of good and laufull monney of Englande at the feaste of St MichaellMichaell: e written over tharchaungell onelie And yf it happen And … happen: in display text the saide yearlie rent or ferme of twoe shillinges to be behinde and unpaide in parte or in all by the space of eight and twentye dayes next after the feaste abouesaide in which it oughough: for ought to be paide, That then and from thencefoorth this presente Indenture and lease and everye Clause and article therein aboue on the behalfe of the saide Dean and chapiter and theire Successors made and graunted shalbe vtterlie voide frustrated and of none effecte anie thinge in theis presentes before mencioned to the contrary hereof in anie wise notwithstandinge/ In wytnes Whereof In wytnes Whereof: in display text to one parte of this Indenture remayninge with the saide Paule Buck the saide Dean and Chapiter haue set theire common seale And to the other parte remayninge with the saide Deane and Chapiter the saide Paule Buck his seale hath set Dated in the Chapiter howse of the saide deane and chapiter the daie and yeare first aboue written

div.p: It is worth noting that the playhouse is not specifically mentioned in the new lease. Because the 5 April version contained errors in the dimensions of the property, Buck evidently was quick to request the revised version of 6 April. See further Ingram, Business of Playing, pp 157–8, 176–7. The edge of f 266 has been badly damaged by fire, with consequent loss of letters indicated by '.'

div.head: f 68 (between 25 September 1566 and March 1566/7)
div.ab: Item. where Rychard hickes h the churches Landes at Ne for terme of yeres yet to comme Richard hyckes hath built vppon one parcell of the sa Lurkelane which with a therevnto LandeLande: 1 minim for n conteyn highwaye leading from newyngtonxliiij xxiij yardes in lyke length in the fy xliiij yardes and vppon th South. xiiij yardes yt ys ag Rychard shall haue a leas and garden as yt is now for lx yeres to begynne at payeng therefore yerely aft fully to be determyned at shillinges and bearing howse and inclosures th Hyckes or ‸his assignes when a new lease of the foresai with hym in a former lea his assignes all n dymyse

div.head: ff 32v–3v (29 September)
div.ab:
This Indenture madeThis … made: in display script The xxixth daye of September in fyvetenth yeare of the Raigne of our Soveraigne Ladye Elizabeth by the grace of god Quene of Englande ffraunce and Irelande Defendour of the faithe &c. Betwene the deane and Chapter of the Cathedrall and metropoliticall Churche of christe in Canterburye of thone partye. And Richard Hickes one of the yeomen of the Quenes maiesties garde on thother partye. Wytnessethe that the sayde Deane and Chapter haue dymised graunted and to farme letten and by theis presentes doe dymise graunt and to ferme lett vnto the sayd Richard Hickes all those there thyrtye and five Acres one daye woorke one perche and half a perche of Lande and medowe with the appurtenaunces severally lying and being in the parishe of Newyngton in the Countye of Surrye Whereof tenne Acres one Rodde fower days works and a perche ben called Lurkelane together lying in the Buttes of Newington against the west to the landes of the sayde deane and Chapter there called little pyghtell against the East, to the landes of the late Abbye of Barmondsey called mettl melferlde against the Northe and to the orchard of the heyres of Edmonde myddleton against the Southe, And two acres too days woorke and halfe a days woorke ben called little pightell and lye between the sayde Landes called Lurkelane and the Landes of the sayde deane & Chapter called Stewfenne, And nyne Acres one Rodde and five days worke ben called Stewfenne lying to a garden there called Bellgarden against the North to a medowe called marleez medow against the Southe to the sayde Landes called the lyttell pightell
against the west and to the Landes of the Late Prior and Covent of Overyes against the east, and seven acres and one Rodd thereof bene ca Lying : a single ascending stroke, likely for deletion in the Comon Sewer against the Northe to the Landes someth Henry wyatt knight called Bramble Shott against the Southe to nowe or Late Stephen Myddleton called Barynarde against the the medowe called marles meede against the east and the west acres Residue of the sayde Landes severally lye in a close call Lande of the which seven acres fyve acres lye together to the Land of the heyres of the sayed Edmonde Mydeleton towardes the Southe and to the Landes of the sayde Late Prior and Covent of Marye Overyes called the wiffen towardes the west and to the L the Late master of St Thomas Hospitall in Sowthewark and th waye Leading from and owt of the sayde close called horsmon into the highe streate there towardes the Northe and two acres to of the sayde seven acres lye together to three acres of Lande sowthe walter kettell and before that Robert Gaineffourthe Esquyer to the east and ‸to three acres of Lande of the heyres of the sayde Edmo myddeleton towardes the west, And the Landes Late Richarde and somtyme Roger Poyntes towardes the southe and to the Landes of the hospitall towardes the Northe. To haue and to hold all the sayde and medowe with the appurtenaunces to the sayde Richarde Hickes his executours and assignes from the date of the date of theys presentes vnto the full ende an terme of Twentye and one Yeares next ensyuyng and fullyes to be complete and ended Yelding and paying therefore Yearelye to the sayde deane and Chapter and there successours fyve poundes fowerteene shill fower pence of Lawfull monye of Englande at the feastes of the byrthe of our Lorde god, theanuncyacion of St mary the virgyn the Natyuyty of St Iohn Baptist and St Mychell Tharcungell by even porcions during the sayde terme And the sayde Richard Hickes for him his executo administrators and assignes Covenauntethe and grauntethe to and with the sayde de and Chapter and there successours by theis presentes, That he the sayde Richard hus executors administratours and assignes shall during and by the sayde terme from tyme to tyme as ofte as neede shall Require at h there propper costes and expenses scowar repayre, maynteyne susteyne Amende the Common Sewer belonging to the sayde Landes or anye o and the bridge or bridges over the same Sewer if any be and hedges dyches and enclosures suffycyently dyked fensed and e shall also beare all manner of skottes Lotes Taxes and Cess to be cessed or Taxed vpon the sayde Landes during the s the same Sewer bridge or bridges hedges and dyches sufficientlye Repayred amended dyked skowered enclosed the sayde Landes Clearlye discharged of all s and other encombraunces in thende of the sayde
yelde vp. And if it happen the sayde yearely Rent or farme of fyve poundes fowerteene shillinges ‸of fower pence to be behynde and vnpayde, in parte or in all by the space of fowerteene dayes next after any of the feaste or featses aboue sayde in whiche it ought to be payed Or if the abovenamyd Richard Hickes his executours or assigned or any of them during the terme abouesayde doe dymyse sett lett or Alleyne the Landes before dymysed or any part thereof to any parson or parsones other then to the Tenaunte whiche from tyme to tyme during the sayde terme shall occupy inhabyte and dwell in the sayde messuag and tenemente of the sayde deane and Chapter sytuate and being in the parishe of Saynte Olave in the Borrowe of Southewark called the flowerdeluce whiche the sayde Rcharde hathe and enyoyethe by Lease from the sayde Deane and Chapter without Lycens of the sayde deane and Chapter and there Successours if first hade and atteyned Or if suche parson or parsons to whose vse and possession this present lease and terme of yeares or any parte thereof shall Remayne and come by bargayne sale devyse legacye or other wyse from the sayde Richarde hickes do not within one halfe yeare next after the having and enioying of the lease and terme of yeares mak surrender of this present Lease and of the terme of yeares therein then to come to the sayde Deane and Chapter and there successours so that he or they may then Receyve of the same deane and Chapter at the time and of suche Surrender a good suffycyent and Lawfull newe Lease of all the premisses for so manye yeares as shalbe then to come of the terme aforesayde with lyke covenauntes condicions Reservacions of Rentes ‸so all other Rentes ‸Articles as is aforesayde for the whiche so to be graunted no fyne nor other payment shalbe Requyred or demaunded but onelye Thordynary fees for sealing and wryting of the same That then and from thenceforthe this present Indenture and Lease and everye clause and Article therein above on the behalf of the sayde deane and Chapter and there successours made and graunted shalbe vtterly voyde frustrate and ost of none effect any thinge before mencioned to the contrarye hereof in any wise Notwithstandinge In wytnesIn wytnes: in display script whereof to one parte of this Indenture Remayning with the sayde Richard hickes the sayde deane and Chapter haue putte there common seale And to thother parte Remayning with the sayde deane and Chapter the sayde Richard hickes haue put to his seale. dated in the Chapter howse of the sayde deane and Chapter the daye and yeare fyrst above wryten.

div.head: Inventory of Plays Performed at Newington Butts

div.p: This inventory of plays associated with the playhouse at Newington includes only those on record. For plays performed at court by the Earl of Warwick's Men, 1575–80, see the History of the Playhouse.

I have followed the annotated catalogue British Drama 1533–1642, vols 2–3, edited by Martin Wiggins and Catherine Richardson, as my authority for the title, authors, troupes, genre and status listed below. Further details of date, plot, roles, staging, sources, performance history and more for each play are provided – as far as possible – in that source, according to a numbering system provided here, by volume. See also Wiggins' 'Introduction,' vol 1, for the scope and limitations, content, format and arrangement of the catalogue.

Others have published their own inventories of plays performed at the Newington, with predictable variations in the titles included and in the interpretation of Henslowe's diary records. See for example, Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 2, pp 118–27, 143–7, 165–71; Johnson, Shakespeare's Lost Playhouse, pp 124–204. For Admiral's Men in particular, see Gurr, 'Appendix 1,' Shakespeare's Opposites, pp 201–53.
The ongoing collaborative work of contributors to the Lost Plays Database, https://lostplays.folger.edu, is a further valuable contribution to repertory studies.
